bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 4, 1956

div1.p: Tate updates Hench on Lambert's bill in Congress.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 4, 1956
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley-3-California
February 4, 1956
Philip S. Hench, M.D.
200 First Street, S.W.
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
You asked me to let you know what happened regarding Lambert's
bill in congrass:

The House sub-committee, Armed Forces, voted affirmative on
January 19th, and the full committee likewise on January24th.
Was brought to the floor and passed House January 25th, and
is now in Senate Committee. Chances of passing are good, for
as I remember they seldom reverse such a non-political bill
having House approval.

I hope it does, as it will just about kill Lambert if it
fails again. He is in bad condition from having an eye en-
eculated and then in hospital with lung trouble in addition
to his other disabilities. He wrote me that he was going
to Washington if called if he had to go on a stretcher!

But O'Hara, his Congressman presented all paper evidence
personally, and that was sufficient to convince the committee.

Lambert is jubilant over the resulytt so far. Said scores of
veterans had told him he could never win. But he naively
believes that right will always win. I never believed that
the Act of 1929 would be reopened and did not think it should,
yet I helped him in all ways possible to me. Then as years
passed conditions changed: There remained but one alive who
could be legimimately recognized, and I felt that had Reed
lived Lambert would have been on that Roll, so I worked with
him with self-conviction.

His joy is marred greatly that Ames has not been honored
posthumously for his work. He is sure, (as I, too,am) that
without Ames the experiment would have failed, anyway until
years later. By then the conditions could not have been du-
plicated, nor any physician arose who could have cured Y.F.
with the marvelous success of Doctor Ames. With all the
famous “experts” there, who had lived with Y. F. and talked
and wrote about it, none even approached Ames in curing it.

Under the House Bill he won't receive any accumulated back
pay as they fear such a sum might deter the President from
signing it.
div1.closer:
Cordially & Sincerely, Paul L. Tate Paul L. Tate
Will be highly pleased to receive the material you wrote of
and appreciate your thoughtfulness.
Tate
